--- title: "Fall of Saigon" author: "DK" date: "2025-04-29" draft: yes categories: [refugee] --- One of the benefits of living in US and working in the Beehive State is meeting a diverse group of people. Including people that were born, raised in other cultures and immigrated from countries all over the globe. Although precise statistics is not available, there are a significant portion of the population that knows of the culture and speak languages other than English (LOTE). It is estimated that 55 languages are taught at the Missionary Training Center and some 65% of the students of Brigham Young University speak a LOTE.[^1] [^1]: Chat GPT ------------------------------------------------------------------------ Working with fellow immigrants have afforded a chance to learn about people with different background than mine. Also learn about their history and culture, without actually visiting their country. Most of all, understanding the common thread of human existence. A quest for freedom, a place to call home, and a chance to improve the living standard. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ Though I have not visited South America I had the opportunity of meeting and working with people from Perú, Colombia, and Brazil all within the same company. In addition I have met people from Bulgaria and Iran and number of people that have served their missions in countries that speak Spanish, Chinese Mandarin and Swedish among others Recently coworker moved into the same building and we visited over our common interest – audio equipment. He is a fan of Nakamichi any particular Nelson Pass[^2]designed equipment. [^2]: We also shared a mutual affinity to analog records. Then he mention that he came over from Australia in 1992 Also,he told he was from Vietnam, in particular from south Vietnam. He was from a wealthy family but when the communist took over 50 years ago, in April 1975 his family was devastated and they look for ways to escape. Using their reserve of gold they got on a boat and endured 2 weeks of travel through Malaysia, Singapore and eventually to a small off the main islands of Indonesia. Refugees were then interviewed by representatives from countries that took in the `Boat People` According to Wikipedia, significant numbers resettled in the United States, Canada, Italy, Australia, France, West Germany, and the United Kingdom. However my friend settled in Australia and lived for a decade before moving to the United States. ## Journey of Lao that took up to Malaysia from there they went to Singapore from Singapore on to Indonesia it from Indonesia they went to Australia and to help with their family he went came tonight states since my father also lived and worked in Vietnam share some of his old photographs that I had on my phone what brings people to Utah them here 500 miles : Vietnam to Malaysia 400 miles : Malaysia to Singapore 250 miles : Singapore to Bangka Islands His boat journey took nearly 2 weeks.
